metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin (Huailai station-automatic weather station-40m tower, 2016)
metadata.description:
The data set contains the observation data of 40 m tower automatic weather station from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2016. The site is located in donghuayuan Town, Huailai County, Hebei Province. The longitude and latitude of the observation point are 115.7923e, 40.3574n and 480m above sea level.
The automatic weather station is installed on a 40m tower with the acquisition frequency of 30s and output once every 10min. The observation elements include air temperature and relative humidity (3m, 5m, 10m, 15m, 20m, 30m, 40m) in the 7th floor, wind speed (3m, 5m, 10m, 15m, 20m, 30m, 40m) of the 7th floor, wind direction (10m), facing due north; air pressure (installed in waterproof box); rainfall (3m); four component radiation and photosynthetically active radiation (4m), facing due south; infrared surface temperature (8m) The soil temperature and humidity probe is buried 1.5m to the south of the meteorological tower, the soil temperature and humidity probe is buried at 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm, and the soil moisture sensor is 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm; the average soil temperature is buried in the underground 2, 4cm; soil heat flow The slabs (3 pieces) are buried 6 cm underground.
Processing and quality control of observation data: (1) ensure 144 data per day (every 10 min), if there is data missing, it will be marked by - 6999; (2) eliminate the time with repeated records; (3) delete the data obviously beyond the physical meaning or instrument range; (4) the format of date and time is unified, and the date and time are in the same column. For example, the time is: 2016-6-10 10:30.
The data released by automatic weather station include: date / time, date / time, air temperature (TA)_ 3m, Ta_ 5m, Ta_ 10m, Ta_ 15m, Ta_ 20m, Ta_ 30m, Ta_ 40m) (℃), relative humidity (RH)_ 3m, RH_ 5m, RH_ 10m, RH_ 15m, RH_ 20m, RH_ 30m, RH_ 40m) (%), wind speed (WS_ 3m, Ws_ 5m, Ws_ 10m, Ws_ 15m, Ws_ 20m, Ws_ 30m, Ws_ 40 m (M / s), wind direction (WD) (°), air pressure (HPA), precipitation (mm), four component radiation (DR, ur, DLR, ULR, RN) (w / m2), par (umol / S / m2), surface radiation temperature (IRT)_ 1、IRT_ 2) (℃), soil heat flux (GS)_ 1、Gs_ 2、Gs_ 3) (w / m2), multi-layer soil moisture (MS_ 2cm、Ms_ 4cm、Ms_ 10cm、Ms_ 20cm、Ms_ 40cm、Ms_ 80cm、Ms_ 120cm、Ms_ 160 cm) (%), multilayer soil temperature (TS_ 2cm、Ts_ 4cm、Ts_ 10cm、Ts_ 20cm、Ts_ 40cm、Ts_ 80cm、Ts_ 120cm、Ts_ 160 cm (℃), average soil temperature tcav (℃).
Guo et al, 2020 is used for site introduction and Liu et al, 2013 for data processing

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: Sensible and latent heat fluxes are important indicators reflecting the intensity of heat and water vapor exchange between the land and atmosphere, influencing the energy balance between them, providing material, dynamic, and thermal sources for weather systems of different scales, and affecting the water cycle process between the land and atmosphere. Currently, there are many traditional methods for observing surface fluxes, such as the Eddy-Covariance system (EC), Bowen ratio-energy balance system, and aerodynamic methods. Among these, the Eddy-Covariance system is internationally recognized as the most reliable method for observing surface fluxes; however, its observation scale is relatively small, with spatial representativeness only on the order of tens to hundreds of meters. The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS), in contrast to traditional Eddy-Covariance systems, can obtain average sensible heat fluxes at a regional scale (from hundreds of meters to several kilometers). Since the observation scale of LAS aligns well with satellite pixel scales and the grid scales of numerical weather prediction and climate models, the observations from LAS can serve as ground truth at the pixel/grid scale for remote sensing estimation models, numerical weather prediction models, and climate models, thereby optimizing and validating these models. The observation principle of LAS is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST), which, combined with the atmospheric refractive index structure parameter C2n and related meteorological data, utilizes the stability universal function fT related to the temperature structure parameter C2T to obtain the regional average sensible heat flux at the surface.
research objective: Using the LAS-related data from Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and Arou Station (January to June and October to November), the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations was analyzed, and a quantitative assessment method for the applicability of MOST was explored.
challenges: Due to the influence of underlying surface cover types, flatness, water-heat conditions, and weather conditions, it is difficult to achieve the ideal assumption of uniformity in practice. Currently, domestic research on atmospheric similarity theory mainly focuses on the similarity relationships of wind, temperature profiles, and turbulence variance. However, there is relatively little research on the similarity between temperature structure parameters and turbulence characteristics in scintillation methods.
methods: Before analyzing the applicability of the MOST theory to LAS data, preliminary processing of EC and LAS data is conducted. LAS, EC, and AWS data from the Guantao station for the year 2009 (January to December) and from the Aru station (January to June and October to November) are selected.
dataset:
Guantao Station (36°30′54″N, 115°07′39″E) is located in Hezhai Village, Guantao County, Hebei Province. Its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of farmland, including winter wheat, corn, and cotton, with winter wheat and corn being rotated. The growth period for winter wheat is from October to June of the following year, while corn grows from June to October, and cotton grows from May to October, representing a typical farmland underlying surface of the North China Plain. In the LAS source area, the area of winter wheat (corn) accounts for about 45%, while cotton accounts for about 47%. 

Arou Station (38°02′40″N, 100°27′53″E) is located in the valley area upstream of the Heihe River, and its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of typical alpine grassland, which is relatively flat. The vegetation height in the source area can reach 0.2 to 0.3 meters during the growing season.
findings: (1) Under unstable conditions, large-scale vortex motion, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales can significantly affect the applicability of the MOST theory; (2) Two new methods for assessing the applicability of the MOST theory have been established, namely factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, and it has been verified that these two assessment methods are reasonable and reliable.

background: For surface flux measurements, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has become more and more popular in recent years. Compared with traditional observation techniques, it can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). At present, LAS observation is not common in China.
research objective: The daily and monthly variation of HLAS is analyzed. And the observation differences between eddy covariance system and LAS, need to be studied further combined with footprint model and energy unbalance of eddy covariance system observation.
challenges: There is much less agreement on the form which universal stability function fT should take. Further more, since the iteration process of HLAS can not be convergence when low wind speed and very stable conditions appearing at night, Wm \ - 5 is specified.
findings: Sensible heat flux (H) calculation with the LAS data of above measurements shows that the beam height of LAS and wind speed are sensitive factors for sensible heat flux measurement (HLAS), zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is much larger than it, and Bowen ratio needs to be determined accurately over wet surface, while air temperature, air pressure and aerodynamic roughness length are not sensitive for HLAS. According to the observations mentioned above, LAS can measure surface fluxes both over homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) in different land surfaces?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method for measuring aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory using wind profile measurements. In the Xiaotangshan Experiment, individual z0m values over each surface component were calculated using characteristic parameters of the roughness elements, such as vegetation height and leaf area index. The z0m over the entire experimental field was then aggregated using the footprint weighting method.

Example.Question: Can you illustrate an example of how the Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) is used to measure surface fluxes and its advantages compared to traditional methods?
Example.Answer: The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) is used to measure surface fluxes on a larger scale, from 500 m to 10 km, which is larger than the scales measured by traditional techniques like the eddy covariance system. An example of its use is in analyzing the daily and monthly variation of HLAS. LAS is advantageous because it can match the pixel scale of remote sensing images and the grid scale of numerical weather prediction and climate models, providing regional scale average sensible heat flux measurements.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that provides multi-layer soil temperature and moisture observations and the methodologies involved in data quality control?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset providing multi-layer soil temperature and moisture observations is collected from an automatic meteorological station installed on a 40m tower. Soil temperature and moisture sensors are buried at various depths (2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm, and 160cm) near the meteorological tower. The data undergoes a quality control process to ensure completeness (144 data points per day), remove duplicates, and delete data outside physical or instrument ranges. Definition.Question: What is the significance of using the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory in data collection for surface flux measurements?
Definition.Answer: The Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory is crucial for calculating aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) and analyzing the suitability of large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data for measuring surface fluxes. It provides a theoretical basis for understanding the relationship between wind profile measurements and surface characteristics, such as vegetation height and leaf area index, enabling researchers to estimate fluxes over various land surfaces.

Definition.Question: How does the large aperture scintillometer (LAS) method enhance surface flux measurements compared to traditional techniques?
Definition.Answer: The large aperture scintillometer (LAS) method enhances surface flux measurements by providing regional scale data (500 m to 10 km), which aligns well with satellite pixel scale and numerical weather prediction models. Unlike traditional methods like the eddy covariance system, which is limited to smaller scales, LAS can offer a larger spatial representation, making it suitable for model optimization and validation.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory in heterogeneous land surfaces, and how might these be addressed?
Definition.Answer: Challenges with applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory on heterogeneous land surfaces include the difficulty in achieving ideal uniform conditions due to variations in land cover type, flatness, and weather conditions. Addressing these challenges involves developing new applicability judgment methods, such as factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, which have been shown to be reasonable and reliable.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods using automatic weather stations compare to those using large aperture scintillometers in terms of spatial scale and data representation for surface flux measurements?
Comparison.Answer: Automatic weather stations, such as those installed on 40m towers, collect high-frequency data (every 30 seconds) at specific locations, providing detailed observations of meteorological parameters like air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and soil conditions. In contrast, large aperture scintillometers (LAS) measure surface fluxes over larger spatial scales (from hundreds of meters to kilometers), making them suitable for regional analysis. While automatic weather stations offer high temporal resolution and local insight, LAS provides spatially averaged data that better represent regional scale fluxes, matching satellite pixel and model grid scales.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when using the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory for data analysis in automatic weather stations versus large aperture scintillometers?
Comparison.Answer: For automatic weather stations, the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory is applied to derive parameters like aerodynamic roughness length using high-frequency wind profile data, which can be challenging due to the need for accurate wind turbulence measurements. On the other hand, LAS faces challenges with the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory due to the need for stable atmospheric conditions and accurate determination of the temperature structure parameter, especially during low wind speeds and stable nighttime conditions. Both methods require careful consideration of environmental factors, but LAS must address the complexity of scaling up to larger areas.

Interpretation.Question: How might the variation in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different surfaces, as inferred from experimental data, inform the parameterization processes in remote sensing models and land surface models?
Interpretation.Answer: The variation in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different surfaces indicates that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions. This understanding can guide the parameterization processes in remote sensing models and land surface models by providing a heuristic parameterization of z0m based on surface characteristics like vegetation height and leaf area index (LAI).

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) to estimate surface fluxes over diverse landscapes, and how can these be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges arise in applying MOST due to variations in surface cover types, flatness, hydrothermal conditions, and weather conditions, which often do not meet the ideal homogeneity assumptions. The applicability of MOST can be significantly influenced by large-scale vortex motion, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales under unstable conditions. These challenges can be addressed by establishing new applicability judgment methods, such as factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, which have been shown to be reasonable and reliable.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways might the utilization of large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data improve the accuracy and scale of surface flux measurements, compared to traditional methods?
Interpretation.Answer: Large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data allows for measuring surface fluxes over a larger scale (500 m to 10 km) compared to traditional observation techniques, which are typically limited in spatial representation to a few dozen to a few hundred meters. The LAS is particularly useful for matching satellite pixel scales and grid scales of numerical weather prediction and climate models. This capability allows LAS observations to serve as a ground-truth reference for optimizing and validating remote sensing estimation models, numerical weather prediction models, and climate models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might traditional surface flux observation methods like the eddy covariance system face challenges in representing larger spatial scales?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Traditional surface flux observation methods like the eddy covariance system face challenges in representing larger spatial scales due to their limited spatial representativeness, typically only covering areas of several tens to hundreds of meters. This restricts their ability to provide regional-scale flux measurements, unlike methods like the large aperture scintillometer (LAS) that can measure over several kilometers.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the difficulties in applying Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in practical surface flux measurements?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulties in applying Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in practical surface flux measurements arise from the complex interactions between various factors such as surface cover type, flatness, hydrothermal conditions, and weather, which often deviate from the ideal homogeneous and isotropic conditions assumed by the theory. Additionally, large-scale eddy motions and atmospheric turbulence development significantly affect MOST applicability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences for data accuracy and reliability when employing different data collection methods such as eddy covariance systems and large aperture scintillometers in surface flux measurements?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using eddy covariance systems provides reliable surface flux measurements but has limited spatial representation, typically only tens to hundreds of meters. Large aperture scintillometers, on the other hand, can measure surface fluxes over larger scales, ranging from 500 m to 10 km, which can better match satellite pixel scales and numerical weather prediction models. However, challenges such as stability function discrepancies and iteration issues in low wind conditions can affect data accuracy and reliability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications for model parameterizations when using datasets that include aerodynamic roughness length calculations over different land surfaces?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is direction-dependent and varies with the heterogeneity of surface roughness elements such as vegetation height and leaf area index. Understanding these variations allows for heuristic parameterizations of z0m, which can improve the accuracy of remote sensing and land surface models. This is because z0m provides a critical parameter describing surface roughness characteristics, which influences wind turbulence and surface flux estimations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What data processing and quality control steps are necessary when collecting meteorological data from an automatic weather station?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data processing and quality control steps involve ensuring each day has 144 data points (one every 10 minutes), marking missing data with a placeholder (-6999), removing duplicate records, eliminating data that are physically implausible or exceed instrument ranges, and standardizing the format for date and time into a single column.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are utilized to calculate the aerodynamic roughness length over heterogeneous surfaces, and how do they account for surface characteristics?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Methodologies for calculating the aerodynamic roughness length involve using an analytical footprint model to estimate individual roughness lengths for each surface component based on characteristic parameters like vegetation height and leaf area index. These estimates are then aggregated using footprint weighting to account for the spatial distribution and size of roughness elements across the experimental field.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the measurement of surface fluxes on a regional scale, and how do they compare in terms of spatial and temporal resolution?
Enablement.Answer: Traditional methods like the eddy covariance system are known for small-scale observations, capturing data over tens to hundreds of meters. However, the large aperture scintillometer (LAS) enables regional-scale measurements of surface fluxes, ranging from several hundred meters to a few kilometers, aligning better with satellite pixel and climate model grid scales.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or technologies enable the effective application of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in surface flux measurements, especially in heterogeneous terrains?
Enablement.Answer: The effective application of MOST in surface flux measurements depends on factors like atmospheric turbulence, land surface heterogeneity, and the stability of atmospheric conditions. LAS, when combined with the MOST theory and supported by data on atmospheric refractive index and temperature structure parameters, enables reliable flux measurements even in heterogeneous terrains.

Enablement.Question: How do different types of land cover and surface roughness elements influence the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) measurements, and what parameterizations are used to estimate z0m effectively?
Enablement.Answer: The aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is influenced by the size and spatial distribution of roughness elements, such as vegetation height and leaf area index. Parameterizations that relate z0m to these land surface characteristics are used to estimate it effectively, especially in heterogeneous areas, where directional variations can be significant.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for the challenges in obtaining reliable aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) data from local observations for regional scale modeling?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in obtaining reliable z0m data for regional scale modeling stem from the large variation in z0m across different surfaces and the difficulty in parameterizing these variations based solely on local observations, as they are influenced by the heterogeneous distribution of roughness elements like vegetation and obstacles.

Expectation.Question: Why might the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) have limitations when applied to large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data for surface flux measurements?
Expectation.Answer: The limitations of applying MOST to LAS data arise due to the complexity of atmospheric conditions such as large-scale eddies and turbulence, which can affect the stability assumptions required by MOST, leading to challenges in accurately capturing the surface fluxes under varying wind and temperature profiles.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in applying Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) to different observational data, and how might these challenges affect the analysis of surface fluxes?
Judgmental.Answer: The application of MOST faces challenges due to its assumptions, which might not hold under all conditions, such as varying surface types, wind speeds, and atmospheric stability. These challenges impact the reliability of flux measurements, as seen in the analysis of LAS data where stability and turbulence conditions affect MOST applicability. New methods, like factor analysis and temperature structure parameters, have been proposed to assess MOST's applicability more reliably.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the use of large aperture scintillometers (LAS) expand the scope of surface flux observations in meteorological research, and what limitations might researchers need to address?
Judgmental.Answer: LAS can expand the scope of surface flux observations by measuring over larger areas (500 m to 10 km), which is beneficial for matching the spatial scale of satellite imagery and climate models. However, researchers must address limitations such as the sensitivity of measurements to beam height, wind speed, and surface heterogeneity. Additionally, achieving convergence in stability conditions and accurately determining parameters like the Bowen ratio are crucial challenges.

Assertion.Answer: The automatic weather station on the 40m tower measures wind speed at seven different heights (3m, 5m, 10m, 15m, 20m, 30m, and 40m) and wind direction at 10m, providing detailed vertical profiles that contribute to understanding wind behavior in the area.

Assertion.Answer: The parameterization of z0m involves using data from experimental observations, such as the Xiaotangshan Experiment, which calculates z0m over different surfaces and relates it to roughness element characteristics like vegetation height and leaf area index. This approach helps develop a heuristic parameterization for use in models.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges associated with data collection for aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) estimation, particularly in heterogeneous surface areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: Estimating z0m in heterogeneous areas is complex due to the large variability in surface types and the influence of wind direction. Calculating z0m typically uses wind profile measurements and Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, but in practical applications, parameterizations based on surface properties like vegetation height and leaf area index are necessary due to the difficulty in obtaining local z0m from station observations alone.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate potential strategies for improving dataset completeness and data quality control in automatic weather stations observing multiple atmospheric and soil parameters.
Request/Directive.Answer: Ensuring dataset completeness involves maintaining a consistent output frequency (e.g., every 10 minutes) and marking missing data with specific indicators (e.g., -6999). Quality control measures include removing duplicate records, deleting data beyond physical or instrumental limits, and standardizing date/time formats. These strategies help maintain data integrity and reliability for further analysis and application.
